p: 3. This mistaken view derives from three correct presuppositions of Aristotelian ontology. The claim that an inquiry into being is unnecessary is rooted in three presuppositions of ancient Greek ontology, the basis for our ontological categories. But before we can interpret that ontology and those categories [= SZ II], we first have to clarify the question of being along with the very source of all concepts of being [= SZ I, especially I.3]. In the present section we will simply review three truths of traditional ontology and the mistakes they lead to, so as to see the need to re-ask the question of what accounts for being.
